title-group.article-title: Capital Asset Prices with Heterogeneous Beliefs*

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2006 by The University of Chicago. All rights reserved.

abstract.p: We show that in a market with an infinite number of assets and investors with unbiased heterogeneous beliefs, asset prices are identical to pricing in the capital asset pricing model, even if prices reveal no information. This result holds despite the fact that in the heterogeneous market the separation theorem does not hold, and investors hold different portfolios, which are generally located below the capital market line. When the number of assets is finite, prices deviate systematically from the CAPM prices. However, we show via simulations that in a finite but reasonably large market the CAPM pricing and risk‐return relationship holds almost perfectly.

fn.p: The authors gratefully acknowledge the helpful comments and suggestions of the anonymous referee. This study was financially supported by the Krueger Center of Finance and by the Zagagi Fund. Contact the corresponding author, Haim Levy, atmshlevy@mscc.huji.ac.il.

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: One of the pillars of modern finance is the capital asset pricing model (CAPM). The CAPM establishes an equilibrium relationship between risk and expected return, with risk measured by beta. The Sharpe‐Lintner CAPM can be derived in various frameworks, for example, a discrete one‐period model or a continuous model with continuous portfolio revisions (as in Merton [1973]), and under different assumptions such as quadratic utility functions or risk aversion and normal return distributions. Ross (1978) shows that the CAPM can be derived from any two‐fund separating distributions and that the normal distribution CAPM is a special case of this more general framework.1Berk (1997) provides the general restrictions on all economic primitives (endowments, preferences, and asset return distributions) that yield the CAPM under the assumption of expected utility maximization. Thus the CAPM can be derived under various sets of assumptions. However, one of the fundamental assumptions that all of the above‐mentioned models share, which is considered as the most critical drawback of the CAPM, is that all investors have the same beliefs regarding the expected returns and the variance‐covariance matrix. Under the homogeneous beliefs assumption, all investors invest in the same mix of risky assets, the CAPM holds, and there is a simple relationship between risk and return well known as the security market line (SML).

The CAPM has been widely tested empirically. The empirical evidence is generally mixed (to mention just a few of the empirical studies, see Lintner [1965b], Black, Jensen, and Scholes [1972], Miller and Scholes [1972], Levy [1978], Amihud, Christensen, and Mendelson [1992], and Jagannathan and Wang [1993]). Unfortunately, most studies reveal only weak support or no support at all for the CAPM. It is worth noting that the comprehensive and widely cited study by Fama and French (1992) strongly rejects the CAPM.

It is quite disturbing that we find such weak empirical support for one of the most fundamental models in economics and finance. There are two main reasons that may account for the lack of convincing empirical support for the CAPM. First, it is possible that some (or all) of the CAPM assumptions do not hold in reality, and therefore the model’s theoretical predictions are not consistent with the empirical observations. Alternatively, it is also possible that the lack of empirical support for the CAPM is due to the problematic nature of the empirical methodologies employed, and in particular the fact that ex ante parameters are not available.2

The purpose of this paper is to examine the robustness of the CAPM to the relaxation of one of its most problematic assumptions: homogeneous beliefs. This strong assumption implies the two‐fund separation theorem by which all investors hold the same combination of risky assets. While some investors do indeed hold index funds, most investors either hold only a small number of stocks or invest in various different funds that do not mimic the market portfolio. This evidence contradicts the two‐fund separation theorem and implies that investors have heterogeneous beliefs. Heterogeneity of beliefs may be a result of heterogeneous private information and only partial informativeness of prices (as in Biais, Bossaerts, and Spatt [2003]), a result of differential interpretation of the same information, a result of investors’ overconfidence in their priors, or a combination of these and other factors. In this paper we analyze equilibrium prices and the risk‐return relationship in a market withunbiasedheterogeneous beliefs and compare them to the predictions of the homogeneous‐beliefs CAPM. We focus on the one‐period discrete Sharpe‐Lintner CAPM, and we employ Sharpe’s (1964) framework.

The strong results of this paper hold under unbiased heterogeneous beliefs. If, for example, the heterogeneous beliefs have an average nonzero bias or are correlated with wealth (i.e., the large players in the market have, say, a positive bias and the small players a negative bias), the CAPM risk‐return relationship will generally not hold. However, as it seems reasonable to assume that expectations are not systematically dependent on wealth and that investors do not have a systematic bias in their expectations, our results imply that the lack of empirical support for the CAPM is probably due to the problematic nature of the empirical tests employed or to a violation of one (or more) of the other assumptions underlying the CAPM (e.g., that decisions are made by the mean‐variance rule) rather than to the fact that the homogeneous‐beliefs assumption does not hold in reality.

Finally, it is worth mentioning that there is no need for complicated analysis to show that under some heterogeneous beliefs the CAPM is intact. For example, suppose that investors have quadratic preferences and agree on the means, variances, and covariances but disagree on the higher moments, for example, skewness. In this scenario, two‐fund separation holds, and the CAPM is intact. In this paper we analyze the case in which there is disagreement even regarding the first two moments, which are the relevant moments for the CAPM.

fn.p: Cass and Stiglitz (1970) analyze the general conditions under which a separation property exists. They find a family of preferences for which a separation property holds even without normal distributions; i.e., they identify separable preferences. They also distinguish between two‐fund separation and the generalizedm‐fund separation, wheremis smaller than the total number of assets. In this paper we adhere to the Sharpe‐Lintner CAPM with normal distributions and the two‐fund separation property.

In a breakthrough paper, Roll (1977) criticizes the empirical procedures used to test the CAPM (see also Roll1978). Green (1986) theoretically analyzes the robustness of the CAPM to errors of choosing a market proxy that is not mean‐variance efficient and finds that the CAPM and the relative ranking of portfolios may be very sensitive to the market proxy employed. Roll and Ross (1994) show that even if the market proxy is close to the efficient frontier, there may be zero correlation between expected return and beta. Another problem with the empirical tests is that they employ ex post data (simply because the ex ante data are empirically unavailable). Indeed, anexperimentaltest of the CAPM that employs ex ante data reveals strong support for the model (see Levy1997).

sec.label: II.
sec.title: Literature Review
sec.p: This is by no means the first study to analyze the effect of heterogeneity of beliefs on the CAPM. Lintner (1969) was the first to investigate the market price of risk in a heterogeneous‐beliefs market under the assumption that investors are characterized by negative exponential utility functions and observed prices reveal no information. However, no predictions regarding the SML are derived (see also Lintner1965a). Williams (1977) investigates Merton’s (1973) continuous‐time version of the CAPM with heterogeneous beliefs. In his model, investors continuously process information from the observed returns, update their subjective probabilities, and revise their portfolios accordingly. Williams finds that at any finite time,t, the SML is modified by the replacement of true mean returns with the “consensus” belief in the market about the mean returns and by adding an extra term that takes into account the dynamic effects. The risk‐return relationship that Williams derives is very complex since it involves the individual wealth, risk aversion, and prior beliefs of each of the investors in the market. Thus it is difficult to derive empirical predictions from this model, and it does not provide an estimate of the degree of the deviation from the homogeneous CAPM that is induced by the heterogeneity. In addition, over time, as the investors in Williams’s model accumulate more information, their beliefs converge, and therefore, their portfolios converge to the market portfolio; thus all investors eventually end up holding the same mix of risky assets as in the homogeneous‐beliefs market. In contrast, in the framework discussed in this paper, investors’ beliefs remain heterogeneous throughout, and hence, investors’ portfolios do not converge over time.3We show that under certain conditions the CAPM holds despite the fact that investors keep their heterogeneous beliefs and hold different portfolios of the risky assets. Moreover, our model allows us to examine the degree of deviation from the classical CAPM induced by the heterogeneous beliefs and the effects of the number of investors and the number of assets in the market on this deviation.

In a very broad study, encompassing many issues in economics and in finance, DeMarzo and Skiadas (1998) identify and analyze a wide range of “quasi‐complete” economies, which may support equilibria that do not perfectly aggregate private information. Their approach allows them to investigate, among other issues, the CAPM with asymmetric information and quadratic utilities. In their rational expectations equilibrium (REE) framework, where prices are explicitly considered to be part of the information set, they show that the SML holds perfectly even with heterogeneous beliefs.4In the REE framework of DeMarzo and Skiadas, heterogeneous beliefs arise from heterogeneous private information, and therefore, all investors with no private information hold the same mix of risky assets.5In contrast, in the present paper the source of the heterogeneous beliefs may be either private information or the different interpretation of the same information, and therefore all investors may have different beliefs (and therefore hold different portfolios) even though they possess the same information. Thus our results are derived for the case in which investors are not necessarily fully rational. Namely, investors may or may not adjust their expectation as a result of the observed prices; hence we do not impose rational expectations. We rather employ Lintner’s (1965a) framework in which equilibrium prices are determined by all the heterogeneous beliefs, but prices do not necessarily affect the subjective expectations. In this sense, the results obtained here are quite strong: the CAPM is obtained even with only very weak assumptions on investors’ rationality and sophistication.

The studies discussed above make several assumptions in addition to the original Sharpe‐Lintner framework; hence they are also able to derive many other results. In this study, we adhere precisely to the Sharpe‐Lintner one‐period model, with only one change: we relax the homogeneous‐beliefs assumption. Our framework and results supplement the results of previous studies and extend them to the case of no private information and to investors who may be boundedly rational. Moreover, this framework provides an estimate of the magnitude of deviations from the CAPM risk‐return relationship in finite markets.

fn.p: This is in line with the frameworks of Harris and Raviv (1993) and Biais and Bossaerts (1998). Basak (2005) employs the representative investor methodology to investigate price dynamics in a continuous‐time framework with heterogeneous beliefs.

Sharpe (1964) formulates the CAPM in terms of rates of return. This approach can be extended to formulate the CAPM in terms of prices and end‐of‐period values (as in Lintner [1965b]). Obviously, in the REE approach the formulation in terms of prices is very important, since prices play a key informational role. However, as Nielsen (1988) shows, the formulation of the CAPM in terms of prices is very problematic because it generally yields multiple equilibria.

For other related equilibrium models, see Anderson and Sonnenschein (1982), Allen (1985), and Shell (1987). Note that unlike Shell, we restrict beliefs in our model to be related to fundamental economic factors and exclude other “sunspot” factors that may be unrelated to the fundamentals.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Homogeneous Beliefs

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Heterogeneous Beliefs

fn.p: This is in the spirit of DeLong et al. (1990), in which beliefs regarding the expected return are normally distributed in the population.

We assume that the total wealth of investorkinvested in the stock market is the same in the homogeneous and the heterogeneous markets. A relaxation of this assumption and an explicit introduction of utility functions to the model, by which the investor decides how to optimally diversify between the risky assets and the riskless asset, does not have a systematic effect on the results. See also the discussion in Levy (1978, n. 5).
We thank the anonymous referee for suggesting this insight.

sec.label: IV.
sec.title: Convergence to the CAPM in Infinite Markets

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Uncorrelated Assets
sec.p: Comment 2.—The result holds for general sets of assets with parameters (μ, σ) corresponding to the homogeneous CAPM. To be specific, assume that the μ and σ are drawn for each asset from some bivariate distributiong(μ, σ). Or course, μ and σ may be correlated.

Before we turn to the proof of theorem 1, which deals with infinite markets, note that we need to define the investment proportionx

sec.title: Extension to the Case of Correlated Assets

sec.label: V.
sec.title: Numerical Simulations

fn.p: Atkinson and Harrison (1978), Persky (1992), and Wolff (1996) show that the Pareto and the lognormal distributions provide a good description of the empirical wealth distribution.
On the effect of the degree of heterogeneity on the approximation for the uncorrelated case, see Levy, Levy, and Solomon (2000).

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Uncorrelated Assets
sec.p: Table 1reports the μ and σ assumed for the assets included in the numerical study, as well as β as calculated from the homogeneous‐beliefs CAPM with a market composed of these five stocks. Note that we selected μ and σ2in such a way that they are positively correlated with a correlation of about 40%. We may have stocks with a relatively low μ and large σ, but in general μ and σ tend to increase together, as found in most empirical studies (see Lintner1965b; Douglas1969; Levy1978). The results reported below are not sensitive to the choice of these parameters.

We conduct 10 simulations for each set of parameters (each simulation with a different set of ε realizations). We report the results for markets of 100, 1,000, and 10,000 investors. The parameters \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $\mu ^{*}$ \end{document} and \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $\beta ^{*}$ \end{document} correspond to the tenth simulation in the heterogeneous model.

It is important to stress that the convergence of prices to the CAPM prices occurs despite of the fact that investors hold various inefficient portfolios, which are located below the CML.Figure 5shows the location of investors’ portfolios in the mean‐variance plane relative to the CML as found in the tenth simulation. As we can see from this figure, investors lose in expected utility terms because of their heterogeneous expectations. For each portfolio we calculate the mean and standard deviation and then compare it to a portfolio with the same standard deviation but located on the CML. The vertical line (e.g., segmentainfig. 5) measures the loss in terms of expected return. We find that the average loss across all 1,000 portfolios is 0.82%, with a maximum loss of 4.54%. Thus, even though the CAPM pricing and risk‐return relationship are maintained, investors incur a substantial welfare loss in the heterogeneous market.14
Fig. 5.—
Investors' portfolios and the efficient frontier (the tenth simulation): a market with 20 stocks, 1,000 investors, and a heterogeneity factor of 30%. The average loss is 0.82%; the maximum loss is 4.54%.

fn.p: Levy, Benita, and Levy (2006) discuss the implications of this point to the necessity of financial disclosure regulation.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Correlated Assets
sec.p:
We first repeat the previous simulations, which where performed assuming no correlations, but this time with (mildly) correlated stocks.Table 6provides the assumed correlations for the 20‐stock case. We emphasize that these are the same 20 stocks with the same μ and σ2as reported intable 1, but now we add nonzero correlations for some pairs of the stocks.Table 7reports the simulation results. sec.label: VI.
sec.title: Concluding Remarks
sec.p: One of the fundamental assumptions of the CAPM (as well as of various versions and extensions of this model) is the assumption of homogeneous beliefs, from which the two‐fund separation theorem emerges, implying that all investors hold the same portfolio of risky assets—quite an unrealistic result.

The analysis in this paper leads to the conclusion that in realistically large markets the CAPM risk‐return relationship is expected to be very robust to the relaxation of the homogeneous‐beliefs assumption. It would therefore seem that heterogeneous beliefs are not likely to be the reason for the lack of convincing empirical support for the CAPM. This leaves the other assumptions of the model or the problematic nature of the empirical methodologies employed to validate the CAPM as a prime suspects. This conclusion is in line with recent experimental studies that circumvent the measurement problems of the empirical studies and find strong support for the CAPM.
